title: Processing and control of novel nanomaterials in packaging, automotive and solar panel processing lines
abstract: Nanocomposites are promising for many sectors, as they can make polymers stronger, less water and gas permeable, tune surface properties, add functionalities such as antimicrobial effects. In spite of intensive research activities, significant efforts are still needed to deploy the full potential of nanotechnology in the industry. The main challenge is still obtaining a proper nanostructuring of the nanoparticles, especially when transferring it to industrial scale, further improvements are clearly needed in terms of processing and control. The OptiNanoPro project will develop different approaches for the introduction of nanotechnology into packaging, automotive and photovoltaic materials production lines. In particular, the project will focus on the development and industrial integration of tailored online dispersion and monitoring systems to ensure a constant quality of delivered materials. In terms of improved functionalities, nanotechnology can provide packaging with improved barrier properties as well as repellent properties resulting in easy-to-empty features that will on the one hand reduce wastes at consumer level and, on the other hand, improve their acceptability by recyclers. Likewise, solar panels can be self-cleaning to increase their effectiveness and extend the period between their maintenance and their lifetime by filtering UV light leading to material weathering. In the automotive sector, lightweight parts can be obtained for greater fuel efficiency. To this end, a group of end-user industries from Europe covering the supply and value chain of the 3 target sectors and using a range of converting processes such as coating and lamination, compounding, injection/co-injection and electrospray nanodeposition, supported by selected RTDs and number of technological SMEs, will work together on integrating new nanotechnologies in existing production lines, while also taking into account nanosafety, environmental, productivity and cost-effectiveness issues.

motivations: Despite the potential of nanocomposites, significant challenges remain in scaling up and controlling the processing of nanomaterials for industrial applications.
Current nanotechnology lacks proper nanostructuring of nanoparticles, hindering its full deployment in various sectors.
objectives: Develop and integrate tailored online dispersion and monitoring systems to ensure consistent quality of nanomaterials in production lines.
Improve the functionalities of packaging, automotive, and photovoltaic materials through the introduction of nanotechnology.
Enhance the industrial-scale processing and control of nanomaterials while addressing nanosafety, environmental, and cost-effectiveness concerns.
methods: Collaborate with end-user industries, RTDs, and technological SMEs to integrate new nanotechnologies into existing production lines.
Employ various converting processes such as coating, lamination, compounding, injection, and electrospray nanodeposition to develop novel nanomaterials.
Focus on ensuring nanosafety, environmental sustainability, productivity, and cost-effectiveness in the development and industrial integration of nanotechnologies.
results: Improve the barrier and repellent properties of packaging materials, reducing waste and increasing recyclability.
Enhance the efficiency and lifespan of solar panels through self-cleaning and UV filtering capabilities.
Develop lightweight automotive parts for greater fuel efficiency.
